''Shamlat deh'', ''Devbani''
([[Alwar]]), ''Jogmaya'' | |- | [[Sikkim]] | 56 | ''Gumpa forests''
(since attached
to monasteries) | S. S. Dash S. S. Dash, [http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/aug102005/427.pdf Kabi sacred grove of North Sikkim] Current Science, Vol 89, No 3, 10 Aug 2005
Dudley et al. |- | [[Tamil Nadu]] | 503 | ''Kovil Kadu'' | M. Amrithalingam M. Amirthalingam, Sacred Groves of Tamil Nadu – A Survey, CPR Environmental Education Centre, Chennai, India, p. 191, 1998 |- | [[Telangana]] | 65 | | Kailash C. Malhotra et al. |- | [[Uttarakhand]] | 18* | ''Devbhumi'', ''Bugyal''
(sacred alpine
meadows) | Anthwal et al. Ashish Anthwal, Ramesh C. Sharma, and Archana Sharma, [http://www.americanscience.org/journals/am-sci/0202/07-0114-anthwal.doc Sacred Groves: Traditional Way of Conserving Plant Diversity in Garhwal Himalaya, Uttaranchal], The Journal of American Science, 2(2), 2006, Anthwal et al., Sacred Groves: Conserving Plant Diversity |- | [[West Bengal]] | 670* | ''Garamthan'', ''Harithan'',
''Jahera'', ''Sabitrithan'',
''Santalburithan'' | R. K. Bhakat Ram Kumar Bhakat, Socio-religious and ecological perspective of a sacred grove from Midnapore district, West Bengal, Science and Culture (Sci. Cult.), 2003, vol. 69, no 11-12, pp. 371-374 |} All numbers are quoted from the records of the ''C.P.R. Environmental Education Centre'' of the Government of India. Starred numbers are likely to increase. The centre also maintains a complete list of identified sacred groves in India, most of which is online.[http://ecoheritage.cpreec.org/innerpageof.php?$mFJyBfKPkE6 Database] at the CPR Environmental Education Centre ==Uses== '''Traditional uses''': One of the most important traditional uses of sacred groves was that it acted as a repository for various [[Ayurvedic]] medicines. Other uses involved a source of replenishable resources like fruits and honey. However, in most sacred groves it was taboo to hunt or chop wood. The vegetation cover helps reduce soil erosion and prevents [[desertification]], as in [[Rajasthan]]. The groves are often associated with ponds and streams, and meet water requirements of local communities. They sometimes help in recharging [[aquifer]]s as well. '''Modern uses''': In modern times, sacred groves have become [[biodiversity hotspot]]s, as various species seek refuge in the areas due to progressive habitat destruction, and hunting. Sacred groves often contain plant and animal species that have become extinct in neighboring areas. They therefore harbor great genetic diversity. Besides this, sacred groves in urban landscapes act as "lungs" to the city as well, providing much needed vegetation cover. ==Threats== Threats to the grove include [[urbanization]], [[over-exploitation]] of resources (like [[overgrazing]] and excessive firewood collection), and environmental destruction due to religious practices. While many of the groves are looked upon as abodes of Hindu gods, in the recent past a number of them have been partially cleared for construction of shrines and temples. Other threats to the sacred groves include invasion by [[invasive species]], like the [[invasive weed]]s ''[[Chromolaena odorata]]'', ''[[Lantana camara]]'' and ''[[Prosopis juliflora]]''. == See also == * [[List of types of formally designated forests]] * [[Indian Council of Forestry Research and Education]] ==Traditions== A large number of distinct local art forms and folk traditions are associated with the deities of sacred groves, and are an important cultural aspect closely associated with sacred traditions. Ritualistic dances and dramatizations based on the local deities that protect the groves are called ''Theyyam'' in Kerala and ''Nagmandalam'', among other names, in [[Karnataka]]. Often, elaborate rituals and traditions are associated with sacred groves,Chris A. Gregory, [http://www.krepublishers.com/02-Journals/JSS/JSS-08-0-000-000-2004-Web/JSS-08-2-085-178-2004-Abst-PDF/JSS-08-2-093-104-2004-Gregory/JSS-08-2-093-104-2004-Gregory.pdf The Oral Epics of the Women of the Dandakaranya Plateau: A Preliminary Mapping], J. Soc. Sci., 8(2): 93-104 (2004) as are associated [[Folklore|folk tale]]s and folk mythology. ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Further reading=== * [http://google.com/search?q=cache:k5aD-8ZEqdcJ:www.ces.iisc.ernet.in/biodiversity/sahyadri_enews/newsletter/issue30/M%2520D%2520S%2520Chandran.pdf+%22+Ankola+High+Forests%22&cd=4&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=ca&client=firefox-a Shifting Cultivation, Sacred Groves and Conflicts in Colonial Forest Policy in the Western Ghats.] M. D. Subash Chandran; Chapter Twenty-two. PDF [http://www.ces.iisc.ernet.in/biodiversity/sahyadri_enews/newsletter/issue30/M%20D%20S%20Chandran.pdf] * [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:gLUpPqllKpQJ:www.ces.iisc.ernet.in/biodiversity/sahyadri_enews/newsletter/issue4/Yogesh_CEdimensions.pdf+Floristic+elements+and+distribution+pattern+in+the+flora+of+Chotanagpur+%28Bihar%29+India&hl=en&gl=ca&sig=AHIEtbQIfGI5RwxoADEO9H5tn-PQY4ZvtA CULTURAL AND ECOLOGICAL DIMENSIONS OF SACRED GROVES IN INDIA] By Kailash C. Malhotra, Yogesh Gokhale, Sudipto Chatterjee, Sanjeev Srivastava. Indian National Science Academy, New Delhi & Indira Gandhi Rashtriya Manav Sangrahalaya, Bhopal; June, 2001. Published by: Indian National Science Academy, Bhopal. Printed at : Nirmal Vijay Printer, New Delhi. PDF [http://www.ces.iisc.ernet.in/biodiversity/sahyadri_enews/newsletter/issue4/Yogesh_CEdimensions.pdf] * [https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:6GXHNAHh4BMJ:wgbis.ces.iisc.ernet.in/biodiversity/sahyadri_enews/newsletter/issue4/Yogesh_Anno_bib.pdf+Floristic+elements+and+distribution+pattern+in+the+flora+of+Chotanagpur+%28Bihar%29+India&hl=en&gl=ca&sig=AHIEtbTV62SpR0jZ-8bC4bOMZHXjgHf8Lw SACRED GROVES OF INDIA : AN ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY]; By Kailash C. Malhotra, Yogesh Gokhale, Ketaki Das. INDIAN NATIONAL SCIENCE ACADEMY AND DEVELOPMENT ALLIANCE; © Development Alliance, New Delhi (www.dev-alliance.com); August, 2001. Environmental Education Centre is a Centre of Excellence of the Ministry of Environment and Forests, Government of India. Home page [http://www.ecoheritage.cpreec.org/index.php] {{Worship in Hinduism}} [[Category:Communal forests of India]] [[Category:Indian traditions]] [[Category:Sacred groves]] [[Category:Sacred trees in Hinduism]] {{commons category|Hindu shrines in Kerala}} {{coord missing|Kerala}} [[Category:Hindu temples in Kerala]]

[[File:Neutron star merger animation ending with kilonova explosion.webm|thumb|This artist's impression video shows how two tiny but very dense neutron stars merge via gravitational wave radiation and then explode as a kilonova.]]
A '''kilonova''' (also called a '''macronova''' or '''r-process supernova''') is a [[transient astronomical event]] that occurs in a compact [[binary system]] when two [[neutron star]]s or a neutron star and a [[black hole]] merge into each other. Kilonovae are thought to emit short [[gamma-ray burst]]s and strong electromagnetic radiation due to the [[radioactive decay]] of heavy [[r-process]] nuclei that are produced and ejected fairly [[isotropic]]ally during the merger process.<ref name=Tanvir2013>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1038/nature12505 |pmid=23912055 |title=A 'kilonova' associated with the short-duration γ-ray burst GRB 130603B |journal=Nature |volume=500 |issue=7464 |pages=547–9 |year=2013 |last1=Tanvir |first1=N. R. |last2=Levan |first2=A. J. |last3=Fruchter |first3=A. S. |last4=Hjorth |first4=J. |last5=Hounsell |first5=R. A. |last6=Wiersema |first6=K. |last7=Tunnicliffe |first7=R. L. |arxiv=1306.4971 |bibcode=2013Natur.500..547T }}</ref>
The term ''kilonova'' was introduced by Metzger ''et al.'' in 2010<ref name=Metzger2010/> to characterize the peak brightness, which they showed reaches 1000 times that of a classical [[nova]]. They are 1/10th to 1/100th the brightness of a typical supernova, the self-detonation of a massive star.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hubble captures infrared glow of a kilonova blast |url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/images/opo1329a/ |publisher=spacetelescope.org |date=5 August 2013 |accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>
The first kilonova to be found was detected as a short [[gamma-ray burst]], sGRB 130603B, by instruments on board the [[Swift Gamma-Ray Burst Explorer]] and [[WIND (spacecraft)|KONUS/WIND]] spacecrafts and then observed using the [[Hubble Space Telescope]].<ref name=Tanvir2013/>
In October 2018, astronomers reported that [[GRB 150101B]], a [[gamma-ray burst]] event detected in 2015, may be analogous to the historic [[GW170817]], a [[gravitational wave]] event detected in 2017, and associated with the [[Neutron star merger|merger]] of two [[neutron star]]s. The similarities between the two events, in terms of [[gamma ray]], [[optical]] and [[x-ray]] emissions, as well as to the nature of the associated host [[Galaxy|galaxies]], are considered "striking", and this remarkable resemblance suggests the two separate and independent events may both be the result of the merger of neutron stars, and both may be a hitherto-unknown class of kilonova transients. Kilonova events, therefore, may be more diverse and common in the universe than previously understood, according to the researchers.<ref name="EA-20181016">{{cite news |author=[[University of Maryland]] |title=All in the family: Kin of gravitational wave source discovered - New observations suggest that kilonovae -- immense cosmic explosions that produce silver, gold and platinum--may be more common than thought |url=https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2018-10/uom-ait101518.php |date=16 October 2018 |work=[[EurekAlert!]] |accessdate=17 October 2018 }}</ref><ref name="NC-20181016">{{cite journal |author=Troja, E. et al. |title=A luminous blue kilonova and an off-axis jet from a compact binary merger at z = 0.1341 |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-06558-7 |date=16 October 2018 |journal=[[Nature Communications]] |volume=9 |number=4089 (2018) |doi=10.1038/s41467-018-06558-7 |accessdate=17 October 2018 }}</ref><ref name="NASA-20181016">{{cite news |last=Mohon |first=Lee |title=GRB 150101B: A Distant Cousin to GW170817 |url=https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/chandra/images/grb-150101b-a-distant-cousin-to-gw170817.html |date=16 October 2018 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=17 October 2018 }}</ref><ref name="SPC-20181017">{{cite web |last=Wall |first=Mike |title=Powerful Cosmic Flash Is Likely Another Neutron-Star Merger |url=https://www.space.com/42158-another-neutron-star-crash-detected.html |date=17 October 2018 |work=[[Space.com]] |accessdate=17 October 2018 }}</ref>
==Theory== The [[inspiral]] and merging of two [[Compact star|compact objects]] are a strong source of [[gravitational wave]]s (GW).<ref name=Metzger2010>{{cite journal |title=Electromagnetic counterparts of compact object mergers powered by the radioactive decay of r-process nuclei |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=406 |issue=4 |page=2650 |date=August 2010 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16864.x |bibcode=2010MNRAS.406.2650M |arxiv=1001.5029 |last1=Metzger |first1=B. D. |last2=Martínez-Pinedo |first2=G. |last3=Darbha |first3=S. |last4=Quataert |first4=E. |last5=Arcones |first5=A. |last6=Kasen |first6=D. |last7=Thomas |first7=R. |last8=Nugent |first8=P. |last9=Panov |first9=I. V. |last10=Zinner |first10=N. T.}}</ref> Kilonovae are thought to be [[gamma-ray burst progenitors|progenitors]] of short [[gamma-ray burst]]s<ref name=Metzger2010/> (GRB) and the predominant source of stable [[r-process]] [[chemical element|elements]] in the [[Universe]].<ref name=Tanvir2013/> The basic model for neutron star mergers was introduced by [[Li-Xin Li]] and [[Bohdan Paczyński]] in 1998.<ref name="LiPaczynski1998">{{cite journal |title=Transient Events from Neutron Star Mergers |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |date=1998 |volume=507 |issue=1 |page=L59–L62 |doi=10.1086/311680 |arxiv=astro-ph/9807272 |bibcode=1998ApJ...507L..59L|last1=Li |first1=L.-X. |last2=Paczyński |first2=B. |last3=Fruchter |first3=A. S. |last4=Hjorth |first4=J. |last5=Hounsell |first5=R. A. |last6=Wiersema |first6=K. |last7=Tunnicliffe |first7=R. }}</ref>
==Observations== [[File:Hubble observes first kilonova.jpg|thumb|First kilonova observations by the [[Hubble Space Telescope]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Hubble observes source of gravitational waves for the first time |url=https://www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic1717/ |website=www.spacetelescope.org |accessdate=18 October 2017}}</ref>]] The first observational suggestion of a kilonova came in 2008 following the [[Gamma-ray burst|short-hard gamma-ray burst]] GRB 080503<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Perley |first=D. A. |last2=Metzger |first2=B. D. |last3=Granot |first3=J. |last4=Butler |first4=N. R. |last5=Sakamoto |first5=T. |last6=Ramirez-Ruiz |first6=E. |last7=Levan |first7=A. J. |last8=Bloom |first8=J. S. |last9=Miller |first9=A. A. |year=2009 |title=GRB 080503: Implications of a Naked Short Gamma-Ray Burst Dominated by Extended Emission |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |language=en |volume=696 |issue=2 |pages=1871–1885 |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/696/2/1871 |arxiv=0811.1044 |bibcode=2009ApJ...696.1871P}}</ref>, where a faint object appeared in optical and infrared light after one day and rapidly faded. Another kilonova was suggested in 2013, in association with the [[gamma-ray burst#Short gamma-ray bursts|short-duration gamma-ray burst]] GRB 130603B, where the faint [[infrared]] emission from the distant kilonova was detected using the [[Hubble Space Telescope]].<ref name=Tanvir2013/>
On October 16, 2017, the [[LIGO]] and [[Virgo interferometer|Virgo]] collaborations announced the first simultaneous detections of [[gravitational waves]] ([[GW170817]]) and electromagnetic radiation ([[GRB 170817A]], [[SSS17a]]) of any phenomena,<ref name="Abbott et al. 2017">{{cite journal |last1=Abbott |first1=B. P. |last2=Abbott |first2=R. |last3=Abbott |first3=T. D. |last4=Acernese |first4=F. |last5=Ackley |first5=K. |last6=Adams |first6=C. |last7=Adams |first7=T. |last8=Addesso |first8=P. |last9=Adhikari |first9=R. X. |last10=Adya |first10=V. B. |collaboration=[[LIGO Scientific Collaboration]] & [[Virgo interferometer |Virgo Collaboration]] |title=GW170817: Observation of Gravitational Waves from a Binary Neutron Star Inspiral |journal=Physical Review Letters |date=16 October 2017 |volume=119 |issue=16 |pages=161101 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.119.161101 |pmid=29099225 |bibcode=2017PhRvL.119p1101A |arxiv=1710.05832}}</ref> and demonstrated that the source was a kilonova caused by a binary [[neutron star]] merger.<ref name="miller2017">{{cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=M. Coleman |title=Gravitational waves: A golden binary |journal=Nature |date=16 October 2017 |volume=News and Views |issue=7678 |pages=36 |doi=10.1038/nature24153 |bibcode=2017Natur.551...36M}}</ref> This short GRB was followed by a longer [[transient astronomical event|transient]] visible for weeks in the optical electromagnetic spectrum ([[AT 2017gfo]]) located in a relatively nearby galaxy, [[NGC 4993]].<ref name="berger2017">{{Cite journal |last1=Berger |first1=E. |title=Focus on the Electromagnetic Counterpart of the Neutron Star Binary Merger GW170817 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/journal/2041-8205/page/Focus_on_GW170817 |journal=Astrophysical Journal Letters |accessdate=16 October 2017 |date=16 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Nova]] * [[Supernova]] * [[Hypernova]] * [[Supernova impostor]] * [[R-process]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://kilonova.space/ List of all known kilonovae] at [https://kilonova.space The Open Kilonova Catalog].

page.title: List of drainage basins of South Africa

revision.text:
A '''drainage basin''' is an extent of land where water from rain and melting snow or ice drains downhill into a body of water, such as a river, lake, reservoir, estuary, wetland, sea or ocean. The drainage basin includes both the streams and rivers that convey the water as well as the land surfaces from which water drains into those channels, and is separated from adjacent basins by a drainage divide.
The drainage basin acts like a funnel, collecting all the water within the area covered by the basin and channelling it into a waterway. Each drainage basin is separated topographically from adjacent basins by a geographical barrier such as a ridge, hill or mountain, which is known as a water divide.
Other terms that are used to describe a drainage basin are catchment, catchment area, catchment basin, drainage area, river basin, water basin and watershed.
The drainage basins in South Africa do not correspond with the [[Water Management Areas]], and have the letters A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, and X. The Area A comes close to the same area that the [[Limpopo WMA]] seems to cover. Apart from these letters they seem to have no name referring to them. What seems to be the case though is that each area refers to some major river systems and their tributaries (a region for each major river system). __NOTOC__

== See also == * [[Drainage basin]] * [[List of reservoirs and dams in South Africa]] * [[List of rivers of South Africa]] * [[Water Management Areas]] * [[Geography of South Africa]]

page.title: List of galaxies named after people

revision.text:
A small number of '''[[Galaxy|galaxies]]''' or [[Galaxy groups and clusters|galaxy group]]s have been named after individual people. In most cases, the named individual was the person who discovered the object, who first brought attention to it, or who first studied it scientifically.
Many of the brighter galaxies visible from the [[Northern Hemisphere]] have [[Messier object|Messier]] numbers, named after [[Charles Messier]]. For instance, the [[Andromeda Galaxy]] is Messier 31 and the [[Whirlpool Galaxy]] is Messier 51. There are a few other comprehensive catalogs that assign the cataloguer's name to galaxies. For instance, [[Markarian galaxies]], named after [[Benjamin Markarian]], are galaxies with excess blue and ultraviolet emission;<ref>B. E. Markarian (1967), [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1994yCat.7061....0M A catalog of Markarian galaxies], ''Astrofizika'' '''3''', 55</ref> galaxies in the [[Atlas of Peculiar Galaxies]] are assigned an Arp number after [[Halton Arp]] who produced the catalog; etc. Objects in these catalogs are excluded below, except in cases where they carry the name of an additional person.
==Named galaxies== [[File:Holmberg II galaxy.jpg|thumb|Holmberg II is a dwarf irregular galaxy dominated by huge bubbles of glowing gas.<ref>{{cite news|title=Galaxy Caught Blowing Bubbles|url=http://www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic1114/|accessdate=29 September 2011|newspaper=ESA/Hubble Photo Release|date=29 September 2011}}</ref>]]
*'''[[Messier 81|Bode's Galaxy]]''' is [[Messier 81]], a spiral galaxy about 12 million light-years away in the constellation Ursa Major. * '''[[Hanny's Voorwerp]]''' ("Hanny's object") is a galaxy of unknown nature. *'''[[Hoag's Object]]''' is a peculiar galaxy in the shape of a ring. *'''[[Holmberg II]]''' is a dwarf irregular galaxy about 9.8 million light-years away in the M81 Group. *'''[[Holmberg IX]]''' is a dwarf irregular galaxy and a satellite galaxy of Messier 81. *'''[[Huchra's Lens]]''' is a lensed galaxy. *'''[[RXJ1242-11|Komossa's object]]''' is a galaxy in which the supermassive black hole disrupted a star. *'''[[Maffei 1]]''' is an elliptical galaxy in the constellation Cassiopeia and the closest giant elliptical galaxy to the Milky Way. *'''[[Maffei 2]]''' is a spiral galaxy about 10 million light-years away in the constellation Cassiopeia. *'''[[Mayall's Object]]''' *'''[[Willman 1]]''' is an ultra low-mass dwarf galaxy. *The '''[[Wolf-Lundmark-Melotte]]''' galaxy is an irregular galaxy on the outer edges of the Local Group. It is in the constellation Cetus.
==See also== *[[List of galaxies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Galaxy}}
[[Category:Lists of galaxies|Namesake galaxies]] [[Category:Lists of astronomical objects named after people|Galaxies]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add arxiv identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
[[File:Globular Cluster VVV CL001.jpg|thumb|300px|Image taken by [[ESO]]'s [[VISTA (telescope)|VISTA]] of the Globular Cluster [[VVV CL001]]. On the right lies the globular star cluster UKS 1 and on the left lies a much less conspicuous new discovery, VVV CL001.{{cite web|title=VISTA view of the newly discovered globular cluster VVV CL001 and its brighter companion|url=http://www.eso.org/public/images/eso1141a/|work=ESO Photo Release|publisher=ESO|accessdate=21 October 2011}}]] This is a list of [[globular cluster]]s. The apparent magnitude does not include an [[extinction (astronomy)|extinction]] correction. {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} ==Milky Way== These are [[globular clusters]] within the [[Galactic halo|halo]] of the [[Milky Way]] galaxy. The diameter is in [[arc minute|minutes of arc]] as seen from Earth. For reference, the J2000 epoch celestial coordinates of the [[Galactic Center]] are [[Right Ascension|R.A.]]{{RA|17|45|40.04}}, [[Declination|Dec.]] {{DEC|-29|00|28.1}}. A high proportion of globular clusters are located in the [[Ophiuchus]] and [[Sagittarius (constellation)|Sagittarius]] [[constellation]]s, both of which lie in the direction of the galactic core. {| class="wikitable sortable" !rowspan="2"|Identifier !colspan="2"|[[Epoch (astronomy)|Epoch]] [[Epoch (astronomy)#Julian years and J2000|J2000]] !rowspan="2"|[[Constellation]] !rowspan="2"|[[Apparent magnitude|Apparent

revision.text:
This list includes areas designated as "[[geopark]]" on the national level. This should not be confused with members of either the [[European Geoparks Network]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europeangeoparks.org|title=European Geoparks Network|website=Europeangeoparks.org|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> or the [[UNESCO]]-assisted [[Global Geoparks Network]].<ref>[http://www.globalgeopark.org/publish/portal1/]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{TOC right}}
==Australia== * [[Kanawinka Geopark]]
==Austria== * [[Kamptal Geopark]] * [[Nature Park Eisenwurzen]]
==Brazil== * [[Araripe Geopark]] * Geopark Paleorrota
==Bulgaria== *[[Iskar–Panega Geopark]]
==China== {{main|National Geoparks of China}} *[[Protected areas of the People's Republic of China]]
===Hong Kong=== *[[Hong Kong Global Geopark of China]]
==Croatia== * [[Papuk Geopark]]
==Czech Republic== * [[Bohemian Paradise Geopark]]
==Cyprus== * [[Troodos UNESCO Global Geopark]]
==France== * [[Luberon|Parc Naturel Régional du Luberon]] * [[Parc Naturel Régional du Massif des Bauges]] * [[Réserve Géologique de Haute Provence]]
==Germany== * [[Geopark Bayern–Böhmen|Bayern–Böhmen]] * [[Bergstrasse–Odenwald Geopark]] * [[Eiszeitland am Oderrand: Postglacial Landscape on the river Oder]] * [[GrenzWelten]] * [[Harz – Brunswick Land – Eastphalia National Geopark]] * [[Inselsberg – Drei Gleichen]] * [[Kyffhäuser]] * [[Laacher See]] * [[Muskau Arch Geopark]] (transnational – with parts in Poland) * [[Porphyrland]] * [[Nördlinger Ries|Ries]] * [[Ruhrgebiet]] * [[Swabian Jura Geopark]] * [[TERRA.vita Nature Park]] * [[Vulkaneifel Geopark]] * [[Westerwald–Lahn–Taunus]]
==Greece== * [[Chelmos–Vouraikos Geopark]] * [[Petrified Forest of Lesbos]] * [[Psiloritis Natural Park]] *Sitia Unesco Global Geopark
==Hungary== * [[Bakony–Balaton Geopark]] * [[Novohrad – Nógrád Geopark]] (transnational Geopark shared with [[Slovakia]])
==Indonesia== * [[Mount Batur|Batur Global Geopark]] * [[Gunung Sewu Geopark]] * [[Mount Rinjani|Rinjani-Lombok Geopark]] * [[Ciletuh-Palabuhanratu Geopark]] * Raja Ampat Geopark *[[Merangin Geopark]] *Danau Toba Geopark
==Iran== * Qeshm Geopark – [[Hara forests]]
==Italy== * [[Adamello–Brenta]] * [[Geological and Mining Park of Sardinia]] * [[Madonie Regional Natural Park]] * [[Parco del Beigua]]
==Japan== * [[Chichibu Geopark]] * [[Itoigawa Geopark]] * [[Izu Peninsula Geopark]] * [[Muroto Geopark]] * [[Oki Islands Geopark]] * [[San'in Kaigan Geopark]] * [[Toya Caldera and Mount Usu Geopark]]
==Malaysia== * [[Langkawi Geopark]]
==Norway== * [[Gea-Norvegica Geopark]] * [[Magma Geopark]]
==Poland== * [[Muskau Arch Geopark]] (transnational – shared with Germany)
==Portugal== * [[Arouca Geopark]] * [[Azores Geopark]] * [[Naturtejo Geopark]]
==Republic of Ireland== * [[Burren and Cliffs of Moher Geopark]] * [[Copper Coast Geopark]] * [[Marble Arch Caves Global Geopark]] (part of)
==Romania== * [[Hateg Country Dinosaur Geopark]]
==Slovakia== * [[Novohrad – Nógrád Geopark]] (transnational Geopark; also extends into [[Hungary]])
== South Africa == * Barberton Geopark * Vredefort Meteor Impact Site
==Spain== * [[Cabo de Gata-Níjar Natural Park|Cabo de Gata Natural Park]] * [[Maestrazgo Cultural Park]] * [[Molina – Alto Tajo Geopark]] is located in Castile – La Mancha region, in Guadalajara Province, about 200 km north-east of Madrid. Geographically, the region of Molina is part of the southern Iberian plateau between the river Ebro to the north and the Tagus River to the south. These rivers strongly marked the Geopark’s landscape, flora, fauna, and human settlement. The geological heritage interest of the Geopark is based on large continuous sedimentary series, ranging from the Ordovician to the present. They constitute a record of major events from the last 400 million years of Earth history. More than 20 sections of archetypical geological formations telling this story have been identified by scientists, with geological stratotypes and boundaries of international interest. The area has been inhabited since ancient times, and includes important samples of Palaeolithic rock art and Celtiberian fortresses that have provided valuable information about the Celtberian culture. * [[Sobrarbe Geopark]] * [[Subbeticas Geopark]]
==United Kingdom==
===England=== * [[Abberley and Malvern Hills Geopark]] * [[Cotswold Hills Geopark]] (proposed (Dec 2011)) * [[English Riviera Geopark]] * [[North Pennines|North Pennines AONB Geopark]]
===Northern Ireland=== * [[Marble Arch Caves Global Geopark]] (extends into Republic of Ireland)
===Scotland=== * [[Lochaber Geopark]] * [[North West Highlands Geopark]] * [[Shetland Geopark]]<ref>[http://www.shetlandtimes.co.uk/2009/09/15/delight-as-shetlands-remarkable-rocks-recognised-with-geopark-status Delight as Shetland’s remarkable rocks recognised with Geopark status], ''[[Shetland Times]]'', 15 September 2009</ref>
===Wales=== * [[Fforest Fawr Geopark]] * [[Geomon|GeoMon]] ([[Isle of Anglesey]] Geopark)
==United States==
===Arizona=== * [[Grand Canyon National Park]]
===California=== * [[Alabama Hills|Alabama Hills Recreation Area]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bishop/scenic_byways/alabamas.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527154158/http://www.blm.gov/ca/st/en/fo/bishop/scenic_byways/alabamas.html |archivedate=27 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }} blm.gov/ca. Alabama Hills Recreation Area. access date: 5/22/2010.</ref> * [[Castle Crags|Castle Crags State Park]] * [[Devil's Punchbowl (California)|Devil's Punchbowl County Natural Area Park]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.devils-punchbowl.com/index.html|title=Devil's Punchbowl|website=Devils-punchbowl.com|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> * [[Joshua Tree National Park#Geology|Joshua Tree National Park]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geotimes.org/mar07/article.html?id=Travels0307.html|title=Joshua Tree National Park|website=Geotimes.org|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref> * [[Vasquez Rocks|Vasquez Rocks Natural Area and Nature Center]]<ref>[http://parks.lacounty.info/Parkinfo.asp?] {{dead link|date=November 2018}}</ref>
=== Nevada === * [[Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redrockcanyonlv.org/|title=Red Rock Canyon - Las Vegas, Nevada|website=Redrockcanyonlv.org|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref>
===South Dakota=== * [[Badlands National Park]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/badl/naturescience/index.htm|title=Nature - Badlands National Park (U.S. National Park Service)|website=Nps.gov|accessdate=8 November 2018}}</ref>
===Utah=== * [[Arches National Park]] * [[Bryce Canyon National Park]] * [[Monument Valley|Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park]] * [[Natural Bridges National Monument]] * [[Zion National Park]]
==Vietnam== * [[Dong Van Karst Plateau Geopark]]

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States (1975–1999)

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{split-apart|List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 1997|List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 1998|List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 1999|date=October 2018}}
The following is a partial '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States (1975–1999)'''. More information can be obtained from the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), an agency of the U.S. Department of Transportation.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page, https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10.</ref>
== 1975–1979 ==
===1975=== * 1975 A Mid-Valley Pipeline crude oil pipeline at [[Lima, Ohio]], ruptured after a valve was accidentally closed against a pumping pipeline, on January 17. The spraying crude oil ignited, killing a Terminal Operator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_16.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=June 22, 1976 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1975 On January 23, a propane chiller at a MAPCO facility exploded violently during maintenance work on it, near [[Iowa City, Iowa]]. 2 workers were killed and 3 others injured by the failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gApRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xcAMAAAAIBAJ&pg=7095,3134271&dq=mapco+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Telegraph-Herald - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 A gas transmission pipeline exploded and gas burned in [[Mediapolis, Iowa]] on January 27. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1975/01/28/86350650.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Pipeline Blast in Iowa | date=January 28, 1975}}</ref> * 1975 In March, a leak was discovered in a 14-inch petroleum products pipeline in [[Mecklenburg County, North Carolina]]. [[Plantation Pipeline]] began efforts to recover the spilled petroleum. From that time through June 1983, approximately 2,022 barrels of spilled petroleum products were recovered from standpipes at the leak site. Remediation efforts stopped in October 1984. Later tests raised questions on the possibility of not all of the spill products were recovered.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawskills.com/case/ga/id/297/08/index.html |title=Browse Caselaw |publisher=Lawskills.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1975 A 12-inch crude oil pipeline ruptured near [[Harwood, Missouri]], on March 26. Heavy rain slowed the cleanup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LUMrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZtQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5027,5448845&dq=texaco+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Nevada Daily Mail - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 A natural gas liquids (NGL) pipeline ruptured due to previous mechanical damage, at [[Devers, Texas]]. 4 people were killed in a following vapor cloud fire. The pipeline had been damaged when a valve was installed on the pipeline. (May 12, 1975)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_42.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=August 5, 1976 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1975 An explosion in June 1975 at a home in [[East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania]], was caused by natural gas leaking into the home from an open main in the middle of the street. One person was killed. In 1973, workers hired by the gas company had falsified records showing the main had been closed.<ref name="poconorecord1">{{cite web|url=http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110227/FEATURES/102270335/-1/NEWSMAP|title=1968: Gas line explosion destroys Roseto home|work=poconorecord.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 On June 11, a leaking pipeline for the [[Alyeska Pipeline Service Company]] was found to have spilled about 60,000 gallons of crude oil at a construction camp in [[Alaska]]. That pipeline had been noticed leaking before, but, previous repair efforts had failed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eWZYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8vcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3857,3322190&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Bulletin - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 An LPG pipeline ruptured near [[Romulus, Michigan]], due to previous mechanical damage to the pipeline, and over pressurization from operator error, caused by closing a valve against a pumping pipeline, at a storage facility. Nine people were injured in the following vapor cloud fire. Flames {{convert|500|ft|m}} high engulfed a {{convert|600|ft|m|adj=on}}-diameter area, destroyed four houses and damaged three others, burned 12 vehicles, and consumed {{convert|2389|oilbbl|m3}} of propane. (August 2, 1975)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-76-058 |title=Safety Recommendation P-76-058 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V6MhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mZkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5210,483573&dq=sun+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 An ammonia pipeline ruptured in [[Texas City, Texas]] on September 3. 47 people needed medical treatment for ammonia exposure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19750905&id=qRJZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VUYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=7046,685830|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1975 On September 7, a gas gathering pipeline failed due to internal and external corrosion near [[Kilgore, Texas]]. Unodorized natural gas liquids from leak were ignited by an automobile, killing 5 people.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB-78-01.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pipeline Accident Reports - Brief Format : Issue 1 |date=1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1975 On September 19, flooding along the [[Amite River]] in [[Louisiana]] caused a 12-inch propane pipeline to break, releasing about 743,000 gallons of propane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dms.ntsb.gov/pubdms/search/document.cfm?docID=299977&docketID=44911&mkey=67002 |title=Document 1 Materials Lab Factual Report 07-122 Filing Date May 22, 2008 61 page(s) of Text (PDF) Photos |publisher=Dms.ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1975 On October 13, employees at a gas processing plant at [[Goldsmith, Texas]] heard leak gas, and investigated. Before the leak could be found, a 12-inch pipeline there exploded, killing 3 of the crew, injuring 2 others, and causing extensive plant damage.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * 1975 On December 18, a failed pressure relief device caused cracks in storage tanks supporting the [[Trans-Alaskan Pipeline System]], leaking about 600,000 gallons of crude oil in [[Prudhoe Bay, Alaska]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vdsjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GSkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6865,4269519&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref>
===1976=== * 1976 On January 7, a repair crew working on natural gas gathering compressor station at [[Cedardale, Oklahoma]], opened the wrong valve in an attempt to increase gas flow. Natural gas & Natural Gas Liquids flow out of an open 12-inch pipeline, and were ignited by an open flame heater. 5 of the crew were killed, and 2 seriously burned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-76-026 |title=Safety Recommendation P-76-026 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> * 1976 On January 10, a gas leak at the Pathfinder Hotel in [[Fremont, Nebraska]], exploded, killing 23 people. A compression coupling on a gas line had pulled apart, causing gas to leak into the Hotel's basement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-76-003 |title=Safety Recommendation P-76-003 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1976 A [[MAPCO]] LPG/NGL pipeline ruptured near [[Whitharral, Texas]], leading to vapor cloud fire that killed one, severely burning 4 others who later died, destroyed two homes, and burned an area about 400 yards wide. A Low Frequency Electric Resistance Weld (LF-[[Electric resistance welding|ERW]]) seam failure is suspected for the failure. From January 1968 to the date of the Whitharral accident, 14 longitudinal pipe seam failures had occurred on that pipeline system, which resulted in 6 other fatalities, and the loss of over {{convert|60000|oilbbl|m3}} of LPG.(February 25, 1976)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_22_25.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=June 14, 1976 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/node/16862 |title=Whitharral, TX Gas Line Explosion, Feb 1976 | GenDisasters ... Genealogy in Tragedy, Disasters, Fires, Floods |publisher=.gendisasters.com |date=1976-02-26 |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5VVOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3_gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3071,2499657&dq=mid+america+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1976 An improperly assembled compression coupling failed on a gas distribution line in [[Phoenix, Arizona]] on February 8, causing a house explosion that killed 2 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_17_19.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=May 20, 1976 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1976 On March 2, an 18-inch [[Gulf Oil]] pipeline failure spilled about 21,000 gallons of crude oil into the Wisner Wildlife Area in [[Louisiana]]. There were no initial reports of wildlife being affected.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1314&dat=19760303&id=MPNLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=de0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=4323,829415|title=The Spokesman-Review - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1976 On March 16, a 6-inch ARCO pipeline failed near [[Tilden Township, Pennsylvania]], spilling gasoline into a stream.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19760317&id=jxFXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WUMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6838,4112779|title=Reading Eagle - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1976 On March 27, a two-story building in [[Phenix City, Alabama]], exploded and burned from a gas leak. The explosion and fire killed the six persons in the building. The NTSB found that gas at 20-psig pressure had leaked from a cracked, 3-inch cast iron gas main.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_67_72.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=October 2, 1976 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1976 A front loader hit a Standard Oil of California (now [[Chevron Corporation]]) 8-inch petroleum products pipeline in [[Los Angeles, California]], during a road widening project along [[Venice Boulevard]]. 9 people were killed, a plastic factory was destroyed, and other serious property damage occurred. (June 16, 1976)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_87_90.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=January 31, 1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=evgLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t1gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5557,335390&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Evening Independent - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On August 8, a house exploded from gas migrating through the soil, from a broken 4 inch gas main, in [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]]. 26 minutes later, gas then exploded in another house, causing a brick wall & part of the street to collapse. 2 firefighters were killed, 14 people injured, and 4 buildings destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR7702.aspx |title=Pipeline Accident Report PAR-77-02 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1976 A road grader hit a 20-inch gas transmission pipeline near [[Calhoun, Louisiana]]. Six people were killed in the ensuing fire, 6 families were left homeless, and a mobile home and 2 houses were destroyed. (August 9, 1976)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-76-074 |title=Safety Recommendation P-76-074 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OiRXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hkMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5762,3395836&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The News-Dispatch - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1976 On August 13, a flash fire in the basement of a house in [[Bangor, Maine]], occurred while a gas company crew was checking for the cause of low gas pressure at the home. The fire killed one gas company employee, burned two other employees, and caused minor damage to the house. One of the crew was using a match to light the basement of the home, and another crew member was smoking when the fire started.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P76_101.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=January 17, 1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * 1976 On August 29, an explosion and fire destroyed a house at [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]]. Two persons were killed, four persons were injured, and two adjacent houses were damaged. The destroyed house was not served by natural gas. However, natural gas, which was escaping at 58 psig pressure from a punctured 2-inch plastic main located {{convert|39|ft|m}} away, had entered the house through a 6-inch sewer lateral that had been bored through to install the gas line.<ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-76-083 |title=Safety Recommendation P-76-083 |publisher=Ntsb.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-09-17}}</ref> * 1976 On September 10, sewer work and heavy equipment caused soil subsidence on a 6-inch cast iron gas pipe in [[Blue Island, Illinois]], resulting in the pipe breaking in 4 places. Gas then migrated into a building, that later exploded, killing 1 person, and, injuring 10 others.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * 1976 On November 28, an 8-inch [[Sunoco]] pipeline began leaking in [[Toledo, Ohio]], spilling about 1,000 barrels of gasoline, forcing a major road closure. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19761129&id=ZhBPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=agIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5658,2451152|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * 1976 An explosion and fire at a gas pipeline compressor station in [[Orange Grove, Texas]] killed one plant worker, and injured another on December 6.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sDwcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xVoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5022,1626941&dq=sun+pipeline+explosion&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref>
===1977=== * On January 2, a gas pipeline ruptured and burned near [[Nursery, Texas]]. Some power poles were destroyed, but there were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dyoPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cIUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7032,502206&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On January 5, in [[Fairview, Bergen County, New Jersey|Fairview, New Jersey]], a circumferential break on a 6-inch cast iron gas pipe. The released gas then migrated under frozen soil & a sidewalk, into an area under the floor of a building. The gas later was ignited by an unknown source, causing an explosion that killed 1 person, injured 13 others, and destroyed 3 buildings.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * In [[Baltimore, Maryland]] on January 13, a 4-inch cast iron gas line suffered a circumferential break. The gas migrated under frozen soil and pavement into nearby rowhouses, and was likely ignited by an oil burned motor. One person was killed.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * On January 18, an 18-inch steel gas main failed and leaked into an electrical and telephone conduit in [[New Bedford, Massachusetts]]. Three explosion followed, destroying 5 buildings, and breaking windows nearby. Improper pipeline construction techniques were the cause of the failure. There were no injuries.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * A gas pipeline exploded and burned in [[Stockton, California]] on February 4, four days after another gas pipeline fire nearby. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LEchAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dn8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6084,1926128&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Gas line blasts interrupts services|website=Archive.is|accessdate=2017-06-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120719085747/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LEchAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dn8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6084,1926128&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|archivedate=2012-07-19|df=}}</ref> * On May 20, fire broke out at a [[MAPCO]] pipeline pumping stations and Terminal in [[Ogden, Iowa]], threatening 4 propane storage tanks for a time. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=19770520&id=7g00AAAAIBAJ&sjid=qCMIAAAAIBAJ&pg=3568,2515323|title=Bangor Daily News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * In June, a [[Williams Partners]] pipeline terminal near [[Lawrence, Kansas]] spilled about 33,600 gallons of gasoline. the next spring, a rancher nearby was still having gasoline entering a creek on his property.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19780404&id=aEMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=beYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3582,476614|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * An explosion on July 8 at [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] Pump Station No. 8 kills one worker, injures 5 others, and destroys the pump station. Over $2 million in damage was done. A US House of Representatives Committee later announced the cause was workers not following the proper procedures, causing crude oil to flow into a pump under repair at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hWQsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Fs0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7084,3305419&dq=pipeline-explosion&hl=en|title=Herald-Journal - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="AAAAIBAJ 1576">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l-5cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0VkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1576,2892833&dq=killed+when+he+struck+a+pipeline&hl=en|title=The Morning Record and Journal - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/recletters/P77_37.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board |date=December 13, 1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JA8gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dGUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4372,1221708&dq=pipeline-fire&hl=en|title=The Lewiston Daily Sun - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On July 19, the [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] pipeline was shut down for the 4th time in a month, when it was hit in a valve by a front loader. More than {{convert|40,000|USgal|L}} of crude oil was spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0i4PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WYUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5538,3708177&dq=gas+explosion&hl=en|title=The Victoria Advocate - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A 12-inch propane pipeline ruptured near Ruff Creek, in [[Greene County, Pennsylvania]], from [[stress corrosion cracking]], on July 20. The resulting propane vapor cloud ignited, when a truck that was driven into the cloud stalled, then created a spark, when it was restarted. The two men in the truck were killed, as well as 57 head of cattle, along with destruction of power lines and wooded areas. Subsidence of underground coal mines in the area may have hastened the failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAR7801.pdf |format=PDF |title=National Transportation Safety Board : Pipeline Accident Report |date=July 20, 1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19770721&id=DOZdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Gl8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4234,2766736|title=Observer-Reporter - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A cast iron gas main broke in [[Cherokee, Alabama]] on July 30. Gas migrated into a home through a recently back filled sewer line trench, and exploded 5 days later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB-78-01.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pipeline Accident Reports - Brief Format : Issue Number 1 - 1977 |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * In August, a car drove through leaking liquid from a petroleum pipeline in [[Lakewood, California]]. The pooled liquid appeared to be mud, but it exploded and burned, injuring a woman in the car.<ref name="news.google.com">{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oiRLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=riMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4950,3987383&dq=shell+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=The Press-Courier - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On August 9, natural gas under 20 psi pressure entered a 6-ounce per square inch gas distribution system in [[El Paso, Texas]], over pressuring 750 gas customer customers. Numerous small fires resulted from this. The cause was an error during gas pipeline replacement.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> * On August 15, crude oil spilled at [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] Pump Station No. 9. There was no fire, but a fire or explosion at that station could have shut down that pipeline, since Pump Station No. 8 was out of service from the previous month's accident there. This was the seventh accident on this pipeline since the start up of the Alaska pipeline on June 20, 1977. The NTSB released three recommendations on September 9, 1977, to correct certain design and operating deficiencies in the pump rooms of each station of the Alyeska system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR7802.aspx|title=Pipeline Accident Report PAR-78-02|work=ntsb.gov|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=biweAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a74EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1995,2906758&dq=pipeline-fire&hl=en|title=Report faults pipeline|website=archive.is|accessdate=2017-06-14|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120717040558/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=biweAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a74EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1995,2906758&dq=pipeline-fire&hl=en|archivedate=2012-07-17|df=}}</ref> * A gas transmission pipeline exploded, forcing hundreds to evacuate in [[Columbus, Indiana]] on August 26. There was no fire or injuries.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1977/08/27/80320132.pdf | work=The New York Times | title=Gas Pipeline in Indiana Town Explodes; Hundreds Evacuated | date=August 27, 1977}}</ref> * On September 5, 2 brothers in a moving truck drove into a vapor cloud from a leak at a gas compressor plant in [[New Cuyama, California]], igniting the cloud. One was killed immediately, and the other died 11 days later.<ref name="news.google.com"/> * On September 10, a pipeline rupture spilled {{convert|69,000|USgal|L}} of gasoline into a creek in [[Toledo, Ohio]]. Corrosion of the pipeline caused the failure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9gpPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YAIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2233,2092915&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_ApPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YAIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5482,3704327&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A gas line inside a building in [[San Francisco, California]] leaked and exploded, injuring 7 and heavily damaging that building. Gas repair crews were working on the line at the time.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NcRiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hHgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5093,1889408&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=St. Joseph Gazette - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On October 12, a bulldozer ruptured a propane pipeline near [[Albany, Georgia]], causing nearby train traffic to be halted. The bulldozer engine was left running, nearly igniting the vapors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=g2tEAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fLIMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1533,2408463&dq=dixie+pipeline&hl=en|title=The Albany Herald - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On October 30, a bulldozer hit a gas pipeline in [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]. The gas ignited, causing a 100 foot tall flame, injuring 4 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19771031&id=1N8jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dSkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3334,7045130|title=The Milwaukee Journal - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A backhoe being used to install a pipeline hit an adjacent 6-inch propane pipeline on November 21 in [[Hutchinson, Kansas]]. Fire broke out, but there were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HmdAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uFYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4762,4003237&dq=propane+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=Daily Union - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * Construction workers punctured a 12-inch gas pipeline in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], with an I-beam on December 1. No fire or explosion followed, but thousands of people were evacuated from nearby buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR7803.aspx|title=Pipeline Accident Report PAR-78-03|work=ntsb.gov|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On December 10, a 2-inch plastic gas main cracked and migrated under a paved parking area in [[Tempe, Arizona]]. The gas reached a building 35 feet away from the leak, where it was ignited by a cigarette. The explosion and fire that followed killed 2 people, and injured 3 others. Investigations showed the main had been damaged previous, and had been repaired by applying a piece of tape, by a non-gas company person.<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAB-80-01.pdf |title= Accident Reports|website=ntsb.gov |publisher=NTSB}}</ref> * A compression coupling joint between a plastic and a steel gas line pulled apart in [[Lawrence, Kansas]] on December 15. The gas migrated into 2 buildings, and exploded, killing 2 people, and injuring 3 others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/Investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/PAR7804.aspx|title=Pipeline Accident Report PAR-78-04|work=ntsb.gov|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MboxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QeYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6888,2848607&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref>
===1978=== * Earth movement was suspected in causing a gas transmission pipeline to rupture and burn near [[Stevenson, Washington]] on January 23. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=V_xPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wwgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4798,1118815&dq=pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Bulletin - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On January 25, a 6-inch gas main ruptured at a weld, in [[Stoughton, Massachusetts]], causing gas to migrate under pavement & frozen earth into a building. The building later exploded, killing one person.<ref name="auto"/> * On February 10, a front end loader clearing snow hit a 1-inch gas riser line, in [[Sullivan, Indiana]]. The gas later exploded in the building, killing 4 people, and destroying the building.<ref name="auto"/> * On February 15, a gas pipeline being tested with compressed air exploded at a seam on the pipe in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] on February 15, injuring 8.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6_pLAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BfkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6824,64269&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A portion of the [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] pipeline east of [[Fairbanks, Alaska]] was ruptured by an explosive device on February 15. Crude oil spilled in a {{convert|600|ft|m|adj=on}} diameter spot.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dhNJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QYMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1891,14355&dq=marathon+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Youngstown Vindicator - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On February 26, a 16-inch Cities Service Gas pipeline ruptured near [[Lecompton, Kansas]], causing natural gas shortages in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19780227&id=Zk4yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZuYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3344,3505779|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * An improperly plugged gas line leaked into service vault in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] at a shopping center, overcoming 5 gas company workers on March 29. Four of the repairmen died of asphyxiation. None of the repair crew had respirators at the job site.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-78-053|title=Safety Recommendation P-78-053|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On April 7, 2 men performing maintenance on a town border gas meter, in [[Weimar, Texas]]. The meter exploded, injuring one of the men. A casting defect in the meter was determined to be the cause of the explosion.<ref name="auto"/> * A gas company crew in [[Mansfield, Ohio]] accidentally tied a high pressure gas main into a low pressure gas main on May 17. Much higher gas flames in gas appliances caused damage in 16 homes, and about 2,000 gas meters were shut off during the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-78-045|title=Safety Recommendation P-78-045|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On June 12, a 10-inch gas pipeline was hit by a construction crew, in [[Kansas City, Missouri]]. Almost 2 hours later, escaping gas ignited, causing burns to 2 men from a crew trying to fix the pipeline leak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAR7805.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pipeline Accident Report |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * A MAPCO LPG pipeline in [[Donnellson, Iowa]] ruptured from past mechanical damage and improper lowering for road improvements. The vapor cloud ignited several minutes after the rupture. Three people were killed and 2 others severely burned. The pipe failed at a dented and gouged area not seen during the original construction, or lowering for road work a few months before. A hydrostatic test on this pipeline after the accident caused failures at 2 other dented & gouged section, and 15 [[Electric resistance welding|ERW]] seam failures in 117 miles. (August 4, 1978)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/midamericapipeli00netc|title=Mid-America Pipeline System liquefied petroleum gas pipeline rupture and fire, Donnellson, Iowa, August 4, 1978|publisher=|via=Internet Archive}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/texas/16844/fort-madison-ia-propane-pipeline-explodes-aug-1978|title=Fort Madison, IA Propane Pipeline Explodes, Aug 1978|work=gendisasters.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/midamericapipeli00netc|title=Mid-America Pipeline System liquefied petroleum gas pipeline rupture and fire, Donnellson, Iowa, August 4, 1978|work=Internet Archive|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On August 7, in [[Lafayette, Louisiana]], natural gas at 15 psig pressure escaped from a corrosion leak in an inactive 1-inch steel service line and migrated beneath a concrete slab and into a building where it ignited. The resulting explosion and fire injured six persons and destroyed the building and its contents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-80-074|title=Safety Recommendation P-80-074|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On August 14, a coal digging crew in [[Cairo, Missouri]] hit a MAPCO LPG pipeline with a backhoe. The gas ignited about 2 hours later, as digging crews were still working nearby. 1 worker was burned, along with the backhoe, a bulldozer, and a diesel fuel tank.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1893&dat=19780815&id=xPIhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jNUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5806,5502186|title=The Southeast Missourian - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On August 28, natural gas, which had escaped from a circumferential fracture in a socket heat-fusion coupling on a 2-in. polyethylene (PE) main, operating at 40-psig pressure, migrated beneath a one-story house in [[Grand Island, Nebraska]], exploded, and then burned. One person was injured; the house was destroyed; and three adjacent houses were damaged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-80-012|title=Safety Recommendation P-80-012|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * About {{convert|7,600|USgal|L}} of gasoline were spilled in [[Hampton, Pennsylvania]] on August 30. Workers boring for a sewer line had hit a fuel pipeline. Later, the 2 construction firms responsible were fined only $500 each.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n4BIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O20DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6977,4457534&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IFodAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A1kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6832,2705698&dq=buckeye+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=The Pittsburgh Press - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A pipeline feeding a [[Strategic Petroleum Reserve (United States)|Strategic Petroleum Reserve]] storage cavern ruptured in [[Hackberry, Louisiana]] on September 22, causing a large fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EQ5SAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QjUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5019,5142959&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Times-Union - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A 30-inch United Texas Transmission gas pipeline in [[Brookside Village, Texas]] ruptured and exploded, killing five people, and injuring 43 others. Seven mobile homes were also destroyed. The blast was felt 35 miles away. (October 24, 1978)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.gendisasters.com/texas/16885/brookside-village-tx-gas-pipeline-explosion-oct-1978|title=Brookside Village, TX Gas Pipeline Explosion, Oct 1978|work=gendisasters.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1876&dat=19781025&id=PFYsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=q80EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6938,6203711|title=Herald-Journal - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On October 30, a pickup truck with 2 women inside drove into an unseen gas cloud from a leaking gas gathering pipeline in [[Preston, Oklahoma]], triggering explosions and a fire, killing the 2 women. 3 homes were also damaged. Flames from the fire reached 200 feet high.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=105DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ga0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4420,4522772&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Frederick Daily Leader - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * An [[Amoco]] crude oil pipeline leaked into the Farmington Bay Waterfowl Management Area west of [[Farmington, Utah]] on November 7. About 105,000 gallons of crude were spilled. The rupture was caused by pumping against a valve that had been closed for earlier pipeline maintenance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=U9pSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WoADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5580,2966936&dq=amoco+pipeline+fire&hl=en|title=The Deseret News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19781208&id=XtpSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IIADAAAAIBAJ&pg=7101,2330229|title=The Deseret News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref>
===1979=== * A ruptured 2-inch gas line leaking caused a home to explode in [[Spokane, Washington]] on January 6, killing the homeowner.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iIJUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mY8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3151,427800&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=Ellensburg Daily Record - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On January 16, an explosion and fire destroyed five commercial buildings and damaged several other buildings in [[London, Kentucky]]. Two persons were injured. External corrosion was suspected as the cause. A prearranged pressure increase in the pipeline was also a factor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-79-009|title=Safety Recommendation P-79-009|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/gasservicecoexpl00netc#page/2/mode/2up|title=Gas Service Co. explosion and fire, London, Kentucky, January 16, 1979|work=archive.org|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On January 18 in Hocking County, Ohio a high pressure pipeline ruptured, killing a line repairman, and a supervisor. 6 other line repairman were also seriously injured. * On February 7, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] stubline ruptured in [[Hamilton, Tennessee]], spilling about 152,000 gallons of petroleum product. The cause was from improper backfill of soil around the pipeline during its construction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pstrust.org/docs/ops_doc2.pdf |format=PDF |title=1996 Colonial Pipeline Task Force |website=Pstrust.org |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On March 2, at Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, Pump Station #6 located near the Yukon River in Alaska, the topping unit producing turbine fuel experienced a flame out of the flare stack which burns flammable tail gas from the unit. Automatic ignition apparatus did not function due to the extreme low temperature of -25F. A safety professional on staff was tasked with climbing the stack and re-igniting the flare manually. Once ignition was established, and before the safety professional could climb down from the top catwalk platform, station management ordered the combustion blower to be turned on and tail gas pressure to be increased from 3psi to 11psi. The action resulted in a surge through the knock out drum at the base of the stack, causing residual oil and naphtha to be blown up the stack, covering the top catwalk and approximately the top 60 feet of the stack in burning petroleum. The safety professional was severely burned and fell through the stack main access ladder components and iron work 115 feet to the ground. The occurrence did not result in a fatality, however, fire damaged the stack and petroleum contaminated the surrounding base area.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} * An 18-inch natural gas transmission pipeline failed underneath the Florida Turnpike in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], resulting in a 2-hour road closure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bAtUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qYwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1730,3097929&dq=pipeline-explosion&hl=en|title=Boca Raton News - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On April 18, a 24-inch natural gas transmission pipeline pulled out of a compression coupling, during a line-lowering project under Iowa State Highway 181, in a rural area, near [[Dallas, Iowa]]. Within seconds, the natural gas ignited and burned a {{convert|900|ft|m|adj=on}} by {{convert|400|ft|m|adj=on}} area. Two cars, a pickup truck, and a trailer housing construction equipment were destroyed. A backhoe was damaged and windows were broken in a nearby farmhouse. Five of the eight injured workers were hospitalized. The gas company's accident records indicated that this 24-inch pipeline had experienced 12 previous failures since it was constructed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-79-020|title=Safety Recommendation P-79-020|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On April 20, a series of explosions, and a fire, struck a [[Sunoco]] pipeline terminal in [[Toledo, Ohio]]. Some nearby residents fled their homes, and telephone service was disrupted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19790421&id=6zFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LgMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6370,7962054|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19790420&id=6jFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LgMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6227,7790690|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On May 11, 2 explosions, and a following fire, killed 7 people, injured 19 others, and destroyed 3 buildings, in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. Soil erosion under an 8-inch cast iron gas main caused the main to break and release gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/philadelphiagasw00netc#page/n3/mode/2up|title=Philadelphia Gas Works natural gas pipeline rupture, explosion, and fire, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, May 11, 1979|work=archive.org|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On May 13, a 36-inch [[Colonial Pipeline]] ruptured, releasing {{convert|336,000|USgal|L}} of fuel oil that damaged vegetation, and killed fish, near [[Spartanburg, South Carolina]]. Cracks made in the railroad shipping of the pipe before installation were the cause.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/PAR8102.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pipeline Accident Report |website=Ntsb.gov |accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On May 19, tank truck drivers waiting at an [[Amoco]] terminal heard a bang, then saw a 3-foot side stream of gasoline pour down a nearby hillside in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]. Train traffic on 2 nearby rail lines had to be stopped during the cleanup.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2002&dat=19790520&id=xOxVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5EANAAAAIBAJ&pg=5318,5174808|title=Beaver County Times - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A "spud" dropped by a pile driving barge in the Gulf of Mexico near [[Pilottown, Louisiana]] ruptured a 4-inch natural gas pipeline on June 5. The escaping gas ignited, and seriously burned the barge. 4 crew members went missing and were presumed dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qgRFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=y7oMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4357,2413019&dq=gas+line+blast&hl=en|title=The Windsor Star - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On June 10, the pilot of a helicopter reported sighting oil on the surface of the Atigun River near the route of the [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]]'s 48-inch crude oil pipeline. Repair crews found a 7-inch crack which passed through a longitudinal weld. Five days after the first leak, at 3:15 p.m. on June 15, the pilot of an Alyeska helicopter on a routine surveillance flight reported a leak north of pump station No. 12 near the Little Tonsina River. A crack near a wrinkle in the pipe was found there. The June 10 spill resulted in a release of approximately {{convert|1500|oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil; the June 15 leak resulted in a release of approximately {{convert|300|oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil; these losses were estimated by Alyeska personnel at the leak site. The spills were too small to be verified by the Alyeska metering system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-79-019|title=Safety Recommendation P-79-019|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * A crack in a wrinkled section of the [[Trans-Alaska Pipeline System]] pipeline occurred at Pump Station 12 on June 15 on the south end of that pipeline in southern [[Alaska]]. About 1,000 barrels of crude oil were spilled.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=w0k0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=k2cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6750,384243&dq=pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Sarasota Herald-Tribune - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19790616&id=ZgNMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JPkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2867,167613|title=Spokane Daily Chronicle - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On June 16, operator error at [[Colonial Pipeline]] caused a prior to installation rail shipping induced crack of 36-inch pipeline to rupture in [[Greenville County, South Carolina]]. 395,000 gallons of fuel oil were spilled, causing vegetation, fish, & wildlife kills.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> * A leaking pipeline released gasoline in [[Granger, Indiana]], causing the evacuation of 400 people on July 3.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lSBSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bDUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2187,281502&dq=amoco+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Times-Union - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * An anchor handling boat, PETE TIDE II, damaged an unmarked gas pipeline with a grappling hook offshore from [[New Orleans, Louisiana]]. Two of the crew were missing and presumed dead in the fire that followed. (July 15, 1979)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-80-015|title=Safety Recommendation P-80-015|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * On July 25, an explosion and fire destroyed a duplex apartment house in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]]. Two persons were killed, and two persons were hospitalized for burns; adjacent houses were damaged. Earlier in the day, a crew from Mountain Bell Telephone Company (Mountain Bell) had been using a backhoe at the intersection of Bridge Boulevard and Atrisco Road to locate a telephone cable. The backhoe snagged a gas service line but the fact that it was pulled from a 1-inch coupling under the house was not discovered at that time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-80-048|title=Safety Recommendation P-80-048|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref> * A 34-inch Lakehead (now [[Enbridge]]) pipeline ruptured near [[Bemidji, Minnesota]], leaking {{convert|10700|oilbbl|m3}} of crude oil on August 20. The pipeline company initially recovered 60 percent of the spilled oil. Later in 1988, the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency required Lakehead to extract more oil using new technology; removal continued on, with studies still underway in the area.<ref name="businessnorth.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessnorth.com/exclusives.asp?RID=3219 |title=Alberta-Superior pipeline takes center stage in world climate debate|accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102001542/http://www.businessnorth.com/exclusives.asp?RID=3219 |archivedate=November 2, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JTFPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jAIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6657,2195838&dq=lakehead+pipeline+spill&hl=en|title=Toledo Blade - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mn.water.usgs.gov/projects/bemidji/|title=USGS Minnesota Water Science Center|work=usgs.gov|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mn.water.usgs.gov/projects/bemidji/results/fact-sheet.pdf |format=PDF |title=Ground Water Contamination by Crude Oil near Bemidji, Minnesota |website=Mn.water.usgs.gov |accessdate=2016-01-18}}</ref> * On August 20, a bulldozer operating near [[Orange, Texas]], was being used to clean a farm drainage ditch. The corner of the blade cut into a propane line, which crossed beneath the ditch. Propane at 350 psig escaped and was ignited within seconds. The resulting fire killed one person, injured another, and caused considerable property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/safety/safety-recs/_layouts/ntsb.recsearch/Recommendation.aspx?Rec=P-80-001|title=Safety Recommendation P-80-001|website=Ntsb.gov|accessdate=2017-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QKUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bucFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5281,5217961&dq=gas+explosion&hl=en|title=Lawrence Journal-World - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * A crude oil pipeline ruptured and spilled oil into a creek new [[Walnut Grove, Missouri]] on August 25. {{convert|2|mi|km}} of the creek were contaminated, and 32,000 fish killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VOMpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MdYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5714,4966726&dq=shell+pipeline+leak&hl=en|title=Gadsden Times - Google News Archive Search|work=google.com|accessdate=18 January 2016}}</ref> * On September 4, the M/V WHITEFACE struck a high-pressure gas pipeline on Lake Verret, near [[Pierre Part, Louisiana]]. A resulting explosion killed a crewman aboard the vessel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2519&dat=19790905&id=7uNhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cncNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2832,418249&hl=en|title=Observer-Reporter - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com}}</ref> * On October 6, an explosion caused by liquefied natural gas (LNG) vapors destroyed a transformer building at the reception facility of the Columbia LNG Corporation, [[Cove Point, Maryland]]. Odorless liquefied natural gas leaked through an inadequately tightened LNG pump seal, vaporized, passed through approximately {{convert|210|ft|m}} of underground electrical conduit and entered the substation building. One person was killed, and one person was seriously injured. Damage to the facility was estimated at about $3 million.
